column2: most of the land in present-day southern Cobb County belonged to the Cherokee and Creek. Two indigenous villages were established near the area that will later become known as Mableton - the settlements of Sweet Water Town and Nickajack. Both tribes coinhabited the area peacefully
column3: with one legend claiming that eventual ownership of the area by the Cherokee was settled via a ball game. One of the earliest known records of white Europeans being aware of the inhabitants is an 1839 map depicting a 'Nickajack Creek' converging with the Chattahoochee River south and west of the Standing Peachtree settlement. Ultimately
column4: all native inhabitants in Georgia were forced out of their lands by the 1830s
column5: and much of the vacancies were granted to European settlers by land lottery.

column1: The town was named after Scottish immigrant Robert Mable (1803-1885)
column2: who on September 11
column4: bought 300 acres (approximately 120 hectares or 1.2 km2) of land in southern Cobb County from the Georgia Land Lottery of 1832. Mable was a millwright and farmer who grew cotton
column7: and sorghum in the area; he owned between 11 and 48 slaves by 1860. According to oral interviews
column8: Mable was a "fair and kind" slavemaster who educated slave children alongside his own
column9: and eventually also liberated his slaves before any government mandate ordered him to. The Robert Mable House and Cemetery
column10: located off U.S. 78 on Floyd Road just north of Clay Road
column11: now includes an amphitheater which hosts public events.More white settlers moved into the northern edge of Mableton by Nickajack Creek
column13: in the mid-1800s. They formed a community initially known as 'Mill Grove'
column14: and later 'Nickajack.' The creek provided ample power to run grist
column17: and woolen mills. A covered bridge
column19: traverses the stream and is now part of a historical district. It is one of the few remaining covered bridges in Georgia
column20: and still highly active today after it was later buttressed to handle automobile traffic. A notable resident of the area during that period was John Gann
column21: Cobb County's first state senator. His home
column23: still stands today and is also part of the historical district.During the Atlanta campaign of the Civil War
column24: Union officers Walter Q. Gresham and Francis P. Blair Jr. of the XVII Corps reached Mableton on July 3
column25: 1864 after the Union defeat at Kennesaw. Gresham replenished his troops' supplies and received medical care at Robert Mable's house
column26: and camped for the night before advancing to Atlanta. The house was spared from the carnage of Sherman's March to the Sea.

column1: The Georgia Pacific Railway (later absorbed by Southern Railway and today known as the Norfolk Southern Railway) opened a railroad station in Mableton in December 1881. The chief engineer erected a sign displaying 'Mableton' upon completion of the station in honor of Robert. The first train from Atlanta arrived at the station just before Christmas. Shortly after
column2: the post office was established on June 28
column3: 1882. This replaced the post office in Bryantville
column4: a former settlement about two miles (3.2 km) southeast. The arrival of the railroad allowed Mableton to act as a commercial hub for then-rural Cobb County. Cotton export flourished throughout the county from the 1890s until the Great Depression.

column2: Mableton Parkway (SR 139)

column1: The Silver Comet Trail runs through Mableton. It is a 61.5 mile paved trail with a 2% grade
column2: beginning in Smyrna and ending at the Georgia-Alabama state line near Cedartown
column3: GA.

column1: Heritage Park is a smaller trail running along Nickajack Creek that ultimately connects to the Comet. A notable landmark includes the ruins of a woolen mill built in the 1860s.
The Historic Mableton Community Garden is located at 5178 Floyd Road.

column2: a local initiative known as the South Cobb Alliance is fostering a debate for cityhood. A feasibility study conducted by the Carl Vinson Institute of Government stated that the potential city would generate $11.3 million in operating expenses and $14.6 million in revenue. Alternatively
column3: nearby Smyrna is considering annexing parts of Mableton. This move would make Smyrna the largest city in Cobb County
column4: surpassing the county seat of Marietta
column5: and ultimately disrupt Mableton's cityhood efforts.
